articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: The ordinary collides with the bizarre in Ben Zankâ€™s photography. Set on the street, on construction sites, or in grassy fields, his surreal images capture subjects in unequivocally inconvenient positions: A businessman finds himself trapped under a concrete block, a wood pile stacks atop one figure, and another precariously grasps the edge of a sinkhole. Often hiding their faces behind barriers or through a distinctly avoidant turn of the head, Zank anonymizes his subjects, making their awkward predicaments appear all the more inevitable and bound to happen to unassuming passersby. More
articles.title: Bewildering Inconveniences Trap Subjects in Uncomfortable Scenarios in Ben Zankâ€™s Surreal Photography

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: In regions throughout Europe, ancient religions often welcomed solstices and equinoxes by crafting elaborate garments that evoked different points in the agricultural cycle. Bulky suits of fur and hide might reference the slow movements of winterâ€™s dormancy, while the straw dresses associated with the TafarrÃ³n festival ask for fertility in the coming year. More vibrant iterations with patterns and towering headdresses are known as boteiros, or the centuries-old garments associated with the entroido of the Viana do Bollo region in Spain. More
articles.title: In Roberto de la Torreâ€™s Documentary Photos, Yearly Masking Rituals Celebrate the Change of the Seasons

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description:
Artist Sharif Bey centers his practice around recontextualizing, a process he undertakes by fracturing long-held perspectives through fragments. His figurative sculptures unify disparate materials and broad cultural references across generations and erasâ€”his works are notably undatedâ€”drawing on both the aesthetics of West-Central Africa, particularly the spiritual protectors known as nkisi, and the industrial histories of his family and current city of Syracuse.
Largely crafted around bits of his own ceramic vessels, Beyâ€™s works are on view at Torontoâ€™s Gardiner Museum in a solo exhibition titled Colonial Ruptures, which questions the inherent value and power of objects, particularly as theyâ€™re stripped from their original cultures through colonial violence and structural racism. More
articles.title: In â€˜Colonial Ruptures,â€™ Artist Sharif Bey Defies the Constraints of Time through Fragmented Figures

articles.author: Kate Mothes
articles.description: Artists know this story well: an opportunity opens for an exhibition or a festival and in goes the application, but all that comes back is a rejection letter. While one or two letters of this kind might be easy to dismiss, they weigh heavily on oneâ€™s mind if they start to pile up. Animator Anna Samo taps into the unique emotional and mental fatigue endured by creatives who keep hitting roadblocks. In her stop-motion film â€œConversations with a Whale,â€ she turns the prospect of a â€œnoâ€ into a fresh perspective on growth. More
articles.title: Animator Anna Samo Scripts a Love Letter to Artists in Her Short Film â€˜Conversations With a Whaleâ€™

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description:
A bold, conical structure stands on The Donum Estate in Sonoma Valley, casting a vibrant kaleidoscope of 24 colors underneath its canopy. The work of Studio Other Spacesâ€”artist Olafur Eliasson (previously) and architect Sebastian Behmann co-founded the Berlin-based project in 2014â€” â€œVertical Panorama Pavilionâ€ is â€œinspired by the history of circular calendars,â€ containing 832 glass pieces arranged around an oculus opening to the north.
Drawing on the microclimate of the vineyard, the studio constructed the mosaic of translucent and transparent panels using meteorological measurements of solar radiance, wind intensity, temperature, and humidity. More
articles.title: Olafur Eliasson Designs a Conical Structure with 832 Vibrant Glass Panels That Reflect Sonomaâ€™s Weather

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: There have been only two documented sightings of the elusive Chirodectes maculatus, a large, soccer ball-sized jellyfish with distinct spotted markings, the second of which was captured late last year by divers from Scuba Kavieng. In what is believed to be the first recording, the video shows the extremely rare animal, which has four clusters of striped tentacles, rings covering its body, and a pulsing patch of red on its bell thatâ€™s likely a digestive cavity, as it swims near the coast of Papua New Guinea. More
articles.title: The First Video of an Extremely Rare Jellyfish Captures Its Striped Tentacles and Spotted, Pulsing Body

articles.author: Colossal
articles.description:
Every month, Colossal shares a selection of opportunities for artists and designers, including open calls, grants, fellowships, and residencies. If youâ€™d like to list an opportunity here, please get in touch at hello@colossal.art. You can also join our monthly Opportunities Newsletter.
Â 
Open Calls
Faena Prize for the Arts   (International)
More
articles.title: August 2022 Opportunities: Open Calls, Residencies, and Grants for Artists

articles.author: Kate Mothes
articles.description: In The Netherlands in the 17th Century, a Golden Age was in full swing. The economy of the Dutch Republic, as it was then known, was flourishing as Antwerp and other ports became important hubs for the commercial shipping trade, importing and exporting textiles, spices, and metals, and the citiesâ€™ populations swelled. Elaborately detailed oil paintings depicting food on the table or incredible flower arrangements were popular additions to wealthy merchantsâ€™ homes, yet a more ominous genre of still-life painting also emerged amid this period of immense growth. More
articles.title: Gleaming Sculptures by Ann Carrington Examine the Underbelly of Historical Extravagance

articles.author: Paulette Beete
articles.description:
In some ways, Caledonia Curryâ€™s work as a public artist has come full circle, an evolution she discusses in a new interview supported by Colossal Members. Curry debuted as a New York City street artist known as Swoon right around the turn of the last century, her hand-worked portraits making striking, albeit illegal, statements on old walls. Today, she harnesses that same energy into intricateâ€”and intimateâ€”installations set in museums and galleries.
When I look at a face for days, when I take a portrait of somebody on the street, and then I stare at that face for days and days, thereâ€™s this part of my brain thatâ€™s like, â€œThis human is utterly perfect.
 More
articles.title: Interview: Swoon Speaks to Finding Compassion Through the Act of Looking and Unearthing Her Own Vulnerability

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: On vintage ledgers and notebooks, artist Albert Chamillard (previously) harnesses the power of crosshatching and simple outlines to render flat, geometric shapes that appear to emerge from the page. The meditative works utilize varying densities to add depth and volume to clusters of cylinders or undulating, ribbon-like forms. By rendering each piece in a monochromatic palette of black or red, the artist draws attention to the meticulously laid lines and deceptive dimension of the forms. More
articles.title: Dense Cross-Hatching Adds Deceptive Volume to Albert Chamillardâ€™s Geometric Drawings

articles.author: Sabina Graves
articles.description:
The Warner Bros. and Discovery merger shake up continues, with increasing speculation over the fate of HBO Max and its original content. While DC Universeâ€™s Batman spin-off The Penguin and Suicide Squad spin-off Peacemaker seem to be safe (for now, at least, per James Gunnâ€™s â€œcalm downâ€ tweet and Colin Farrellâ€™sâ€¦
Read more...
articles.title: Open Channel: Which HBO Max Genre Series or Movie Would You Save?

articles.author: Linda Codega
articles.description:
As legendary war artist Ling Taishi watches the teenaged prophesied hero of her nation, Wen Jian, perform in an over-decorated gladiatorial arena, she quickly realizes that the boy is the worst of all possible outcomes. A deluded, over-indulged, under-trained teenage dirtbag. So much for being the child warrior theâ€¦
Read more...
articles.title: The Art of Prophecy Brings Martial War Artists to Their Knees

articles.author: Kyle Barr
articles.description:
The two arms of HBOâ€™s streaming slate will be coming together as one, a desperate move as the company reported some losses thanks to its parent Warner Bros. merger with Discovery that was first announced in 2021.
Read more...
articles.title: Warner Bros. Will Combine HBO Max and Discovery+ Under One Rather Leaky Roof

articles.author: James Whitbrook
articles.description:
Inspired by the events detailed in J.R.R. Tolkienâ€™s history of Middle-earth beyond The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, Rings of Power explores what happened long before the events of those novels, dubbed the Second Age of Middle-earth.

Read more...
articles.title: Everything We Know About The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power

articles.author: Mack DeGeurin
articles.description:
Visa and Mastercard, two of the worldâ€™s largest payment processors, said Thursday that they will suspend payments for ad purchases on Pornhub. articles.description:
April 2022
One of the most surprising things I've witnessed in my lifetime is
the rebirth of the concept of heresy.
In his excellent biography of Newton, Richard Westfall writes about the
moment when he was elected a fellow of Trinity College:

  Supported comfortably, Newton was free to devote himself wholly
  to whatever he chose. To remain on, he had only to avoid the three
  unforgivable sins: crime, heresy, and marriage.
  [1]

The first time I read that, in the 1990s, it sounded amusingly
medieval. How strange, to have to avoid committing heresy. But when
I reread it 20 years later it sounded like a description of
contemporary employment.
There are an ever-increasing number of opinions you can be fired
for. Those doing the firing don't use the word "heresy" to describe
them, but struâ€¦
articles.title: Heresy

articles.description:
November 2021
(This essay is derived from a talk at the Cambridge Union.)
When I was a kid, I'd have said there wasn't. My father told me so.
Some people like some things, and other people like other things,
and who's to say who's right?
It seemed so obvious that there was no such thing as good taste
that it was only through indirect evidence that I realized my father
was wrong. And that's what I'm going to give you here: a proof by
reductio ad absurdum. If we start from the premise that there's no
such thing as good taste, we end up with conclusions that are
obviously false, and therefore the premise must be wrong.
We'd better start by saying what good taste is. There's a narrow
sense in which it refers to aesthetic judgements and a broader one
in which it refers to preferences of any kinâ€¦
articles.title: Is There Such a Thing as Good Taste?

articles.description:
February 2022
Writing about something, even something you know well, usually shows
you that you didn't know it as well as you thought. Putting ideas
into words is a severe test. The first words you choose are usually
wrong; you have to rewrite sentences over and over  to
get them exactly right. And your ideas won't just be imprecise, but
incomplete too. Half the ideas that end up in an essay will be ones
you thought of while you were writing it. Indeed, that's why I write
them.
Once you publish something, the convention is that whatever you
wrote was what you thought before you wrote it. These were your
ideas, and now you've expressed them. But you know this isn't true.
You know that putting your ideas into words changed them. And not
just the ideas you published. Presumably there were othâ€¦
articles.title: Putting Ideas into Words

articles.description:
August 2021
When people say that in their experience all programming languages
are basically equivalent, they're making a statement not about
languages but about the kind of programming they've done.
99.5% of programming consists of gluing together calls to library
functions. All popular languages are equally good at this. So one
can easily spend one's whole career operating in the intersection
of popular programming languages.
But the other .5% of programming is disproportionately interesting.
If you want to learn what it consists of, the weirdness of weird
languages is a good clue to follow.
Weird languages aren't weird by accident. Not the good ones, at
least. The weirdness of the good ones usually implies the existence
of some form of programming that's not just the usual gluing togethâ€¦
articles.title: Weird Languages

articles.description:
October 2021
If you asked people what was special about Einstein, most would say
that he was really smart. Even the ones who tried to give you a
more sophisticated-sounding answer would probably think this first.
Till a few years ago I would have given the same answer myself. But
that wasn't what was special about Einstein. What was special about
him was that he had important new ideas. Being very smart was a
necessary precondition for having those ideas, but the two are not
identical.
It may seem a hair-splitting distinction to point out that intelligence
and its consequences are not identical, but it isn't. There's a big
gap between them. Anyone who's spent time around universities and
research labs knows how big. There are a lot of genuinely smart
people who don't achieve very much.
I gâ€¦
articles.title: Beyond Smart
